team.members: *Kaiming He, *Ross Girshick, Ilija Radosavovic, Georgia Gkioxari, Piotr Dollár (* denotes equal first authorship); Facebook AI Research
team.name: FAIR Mask R-CNN

description: Our entry is built upon the following papers developed at FAIR: (i) Mask R-CNN [1], for bbox and mask prediction; (ii) Feature Pyramid Networks (FPN) [2], and (iii) ResNeXt [3] 152-32x8d pre-trained on ImageNet-5k as in [3], as the backbone. No data labeled with boxes or masks, beyond what is provided in COCO, are used in our entry. No data other than ImageNet-5k were used for network pre-training. Main results on test-dev include: (i) Single-model without test-time augmentation: 45.5 bbox AP and 40.8 mask AP, which runs at 3 FPS on an NVIDIA P100 GPU while predicting both boxes and masks (ii) Single-model with test-time augmentation (multi-scale testing and horizontal image flipping): 47.9 bbox AP and 42.6 mask AP (iii) Ensembling of Mask R-CNN models for the competition: 49.5 bbox AP and 43.5 mask AP (3 models); 50.3 bbox AP and 43.8 mask AP (30 models) We will release our codebase ("Detectron") which includes Mask R-CNN, FPN, and ResNeXt. [1] https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.06870 [2] https://arxiv.org/abs/1612.03144 [3] https://arxiv.org/abs/1611.05431
VGG16 based Faster-RCNN with ROI Align, single model.

Deformable Attention Network: 1. squeeze and excitation module on deformable convolution network;  2.  single model 45.9 mAP on test-dev. 3. no ensembling on submission results, inference time: 5fps for single scale. 4. reference: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1709.01507.pdf

team.members: Samuel Albanie (University of Oxford), David Novotny (University of Oxford), Diane Larlus (NAVER LABS Europe), Andrea Vedaldi (University of Oxford)
team.name: ANLV

description: Our goal is to better understand the distributed scale representation learned by SSD-style template bank detectors. To this end we use a single model, Pruned Single Shot Detector (PSSD), which comprises a simple modification to the SSD-512 architecture (with a VGG-16 feature extractor), trained on COCO training set. It applies a simple change to the inference pathway of the network to operate effectively on multiple scales and requires no extra parameters or additional training.

team.members: Zhengyan Ding (1), Xiaoteng Zhang (1), Jie Shao (2), Lin Mei (1) Affiliation: 1) The Third Research Institute of the Ministry of Public Security, P.R. China. 2) QINIU-ATLAB
team.name: Trimps-Soushen+QINIU

url: Ensemble of multiple models using unlabeled data with multiple scales.

team.members: Bharat Singh, University of Maryland, College Park
team.name: bharat_umd

description: We train Deformable-RFCN [1] with SNIP [2] using 3 scales (480,800), (800,1200), (1400,2000). RPN and R-FCN are trained independently. 3 networks, DPN-92, DPN-98 and ResNet-101 are used for classification in the ensemble. The predictions of all the detections are combined using SoftNMS [3]. [1] Deformable Convolutional Networks: Jifeng Dai, Haozhi Qi, Yuwen Xiong, Yi Li, Guodong Zhang, Han Hu Yichen Wei, ICCV 2017. [2] An Analysis of Scale Invariance in Object Detection – SNIP: Bharat Singh, Larry Davis, arXiv 2017. [3] Soft-NMS – Improving Object Detection With One Line of Code: Navaneeth Bodla, Bharat Singh, Rama Chellappa Larry S. Davis, ICCV 2017.

team.members: Chao Peng*, Tete Xiao*, Zeming Li*, Yuning Jiang, Xiangyu Zhang, Kai Jia, Gang Yu, Jian Sun (* indicates equal contribution); Megvii Research
team.name: Megvii (Face++)

description: We trained a large-batch object detector, MegDet, by Megvii (Face++)’s large-scale deep learning framework called MegBrain, in parallel, on 128 GPUs. Thanks to MegBrain, we were able to finish the whole training within ~1 day and got improved performance due to the large batch size. The design of our detectors follows the idea of FPN[1], whose feature extractors are a series of ReNeXt-like models pre-trained on ImageNet only. GCN modules[2] and instance-blind segmentation supervision[3] were also applied in the detector. We did not use the unlabeled images provided by MSCOCO or other training data. On the test-dev, our best single detector had obtained mAP 50.5, and the ensemble of four detectors had achieved mAP 52.6. [1] Tsung-Yi Lin, Poitr Dollár, Ross Girshick, et al. Feature pyramid networks for object detection. CVPR 2017. [2] Chao Peng, Xiangyu Zhang, Gang Yu, et al. Large Kernel Matters--Improve Semantic Segmentation by Global Convolutional Network. CVPR 2017. [3] Jiayuan Mao, Tete Xiao, Yuning Jiang, et al. What Can Help Pedestrian Detection? CVPR 2017.

team.members: Min-Kook Choi, Jihun Jung, Jaehyeong Park, Heechul Jung, Jin-Hee Lee, Woong Jae Won, Soon Kwon, Woo Young Jung (DGIST)
team.name: DGIST-FATRC

description: We used four models ensemble with the joint Soft-NMS [5], and each model are as follows:1) Three models of Deformable convolutional network using R-FCN architecture with ResNet-101 as backbone CNN [1,2,4] from different hyper parameters. 2) One model of Deformable convolutional network using Faster-RCNN architecture with ResNet-101 as backbone CNN [1,3,4]. We also apply semi-supervised learning (SSL) with coco unlabeled2017 dataset using pseudo labeled boxes extracted by deformable R-FCN which trained with train-val2017 dataset. To filter false label from the deformable R-FCN, we adopted prior knowledge from coco train-val2017 ground truth information as a co-occurrence matrix. The co-occurrence matrix represent that which objects appear together in a single image, and it will regulate soft-max output to prevent over-sampled boxes from unlabeled2017. And we assumed the conditional independence of each co-occurrence to filter false labeling for SSL. Unfortunately, we did't try multi-resolution testing to our models due to lack of time and resources. Additional remarks: - Detailed in best single model performance. Model: Deformable R-FCN with ResNet-101. Training resolution: [1200 800]. Test resolution: [1200 800]. Inference time: around 0.3~0.4s for forwarding. Training set: train2017 + val2017 + unlabeled2017 with pseudo label. Best performance: 38.7 for test-dev2017. These are main references for our submission: [1] Jifeng Dai et al., "Deformable Convolutional Networks", arXiv:1703.06211. [2] Jifeng Dai et al., "R-FCN: Object Detection via Region-based Fully Convolutional Networks", arXiv:1605.06409. [3] S. Ren et al., "Faster R-CNN: Towards Real-Time Object Detection with Region Proposal Networks", arXiv:1506.01497. [4] Kaiming He et al., "Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition", arXiv:1512.03385. [5] Navaneeth Bodla et al., "Improving Object Detection With One Line of Code", arXiv:1704.04503.

team.members: Zhe Chen, Shaoli Huang, Dacheng Tao (UBTECH Sydney AI Centre, Unversity of Sydney)
team.name: DL61

description: To improve the detection performance on coco, we made the following efforts: (a) We propose a novel proposal generation algorithm based on heat maps that can provide anchors in diversified shapes. The proposals produced by both original Region Proposal Network and our algorithm are adopted in this competition; (b) We introduce the use of both Faster R-CNN detection pipeline and Deformable R-FCN detection pipeline. The results of these two detection pipelines are ensembled for better mAP. We use multi-scale testing for both detectors. The best single model performance is 40.5 on test-dev. The speed is around 0.4~0.5s for one image (single scale); (c) We introduce a novel bounding box suppression algorithm in comparison to original NMS and soft-NMS algorithm; (d) No external data is used.

team.members: Haozhi Qi, Zheng Zhang, Bin Xiao, Han Hu, Bowen Cheng, Yichen Wei, Jifeng Dai (Microsoft Research Asia)
team.name: MSRA

description: The entry is based on Deformable ConvNets [1] and Xception network [2]. The deformable convolution and deformable RoI pooling modules introduced in [1] can effectively enhance the transformation modeling capacity of ConvNets. The new modules can readily replace their plain counterparts in existing ConvNets and can be easily trained end-to-end by standard back-propagation, giving rise to Deformable ConvNets. On top of a strong baseline (Xception + FPN [3] + SoftNMS [4]), Deformable ConvNets boost the mAP by a clear margin (~3%). In the entry, ImageNet classification is the only external data utilized for network pretraining. The single model performance of Deformable ConvNets is 48.5% (with Xception + FPN + SoftNMS). The final entry utilize an ensemble of 6 models. [1] Jifeng Dai, Haozhi Qi, Yuwen Xiong, Yi Li, Guodong Zhang, Han Hu, Yichen Wei. "Deformable Convolutional Networks". In ICCV 2017. [2] François Chollet. "Xception: Deep Learning with Depthwise Separable Convolutions". In CVPR 2017. [3] Tsung-Yi Lin, Piotr Dollár, Ross Girshick, Kaiming He, Bharath Hariharan, Serge Belongie. "Feature Pyramid Networks for Object Detection". In CVPR 2017. [4] Navaneeth Bodla, Bharat Singh, Rama Chellappa, Larry S. Davis. "Soft-NMS -- Improving Object Detection With One Line of Code". In ICCV 2017. URL: https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.06211 https://github.com/msracver/Deformable-ConvNets

team.members: Taehoon Kim, Oleksandr Baiev, Jaehwan Kim, Jimin Park, Jinyoung Hwang, Kyeyoung Jung, Hyeonggon Kim (Samsung)
team.name: VCA

description: We submit three cases: (1) ConcatFPN: concatfpn-test.zip (SingleModle); (2) SE-CoupleNet: detections_test2017_se-couplenet_results.zip (Single Model); (3) DFM-SE-CoupleNet: detections_test2017_DFM_SE-CoupleNet_results.zip (Ensemble Model) We use only MS-COCO 2017 train data without any external data. (1) ConcatFPN It was trained following FPN [1] pipeline with ResNet101 as backbone. In our approach, we crop features from all levels instead of assign region proposal to single pyramid level. Obtained features are concatenated and passed through 1x1 convolution for complexity reducing. Such modification allows us to get +1.8 points in val2017. For final submission voting and multiscale testing were applied. Inference time is about 300ms on Tesla M40. (2) SE-CoupleNet It was trained following CoupleNet [2] pipeline with SE-ResNeXt-101 [3] as backbone. Compared with original ResNet-101 backbone, the performance is dramatically increased. Also, instead of ROI poolying layer, we use ROI Align [4] layer to fix the misalignment in pooling step. For final submission, soft-nms [5] and multiscale testing were applied. Inference time is about 270ms on Tesla M40. (3) Ensemble Model: This is a ensemble model. It combines three models as follows: - Deformable R-FCN (backbone: ResNet-101) with feature concatenation. Based on Deformable R-FCN, we add feature concatenation with three levels for classification. Inference time is about 400ms on Tesla M40. - Deformable CoupleNet (backbone: SE-ResNet-101) with ROI Align. We use SE-ResNet-101 [3] as backbone. In order to improve the performance, we add deformable convolutional layers and deformable roi pooling [6] in CoupleNet. Also, ROI Align [4] is used to fix the misalignment in pooling step. Inference time is about 300ms on Tesla M40. - CoupleNet (SE-ResNeXt-101) with ROI Align. This is same to (2) SE-CoupleNet. For final submission, soft-nms [5] and multiscale testing were applied. [1] FPN: "Feature Pyramid Networks for Object Detection", https://arxiv.org/abs/1612.03144 [2] CoupleNet: "CoupleNet: Coupling Global Structure with Local Parts for Object Detection", https://arxiv.org/abs/1708.02863 [3] SE-ResNet-101, SE-ResNeXt-101: "Squeeze-and-Excitation Networks", https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.01507 [4] ROI Align: "Mask R-CNN", https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.06870 [5] soft-nms: "Improving Object Detection With One Line of Code", https://arxiv.org/abs/1704.04503 [6] Deformable: "Deformable Convolutional Networks", https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.06211
Deformable convolutional network with rfcn and softnms. The baseline model is senet. No external data used. The performance is the single model. I did not use any ensembling model.

team.members: Tao Kong, Hao Zhao, Ming Lu, Anbang Yao, Xia Zhu, Nataraj Jammalamadaka, Yurong Chen (Intel Labs)
team.name: IL

description: Based on Faster RCNN baseline, we add hyperfeatures[1]. For better detection of small objects, we also add local context at detection stage. As for post-processing we apply soft-nms[2]. Models are pre-trained on ImageNet and fine-tuned on COCO 2014 train+val35 sets. During test-time we use horizontal image flipping and five image scales (488, 576, 800, 1000 and 1200). No external data is used. One single model gets 41.1 mAP on Test-dev2017. We use only 3 models for ensemble.   [1] Kong T, Yao A, Chen Y, et al. Hypernet: Towards accurate region proposal generation and joint object detection. In CVPR2016 [2] Bodla N, Singh B, Chellappa R, et al. Improving Object Detection With One Line of Code, In ICCV2017

team.members: Seongmin Kang, Seonghoon Kim, Yusun Lim, Kibum Bae, Heungwoo Han
team.name: LDL

description: - Training data: imagenet classificatin dataset for pretrained network; ms coco detection dataset (exclude minival). - Best single model performance: 40.0% mAP with multi-scale inference. - models for ensemble * retinanet detection model (Tsung-Yi Lin, Priya Goyal, Ross Girshick, Kaiming He, Piotr Dollár. Focal Loss for Dense Object Detection ). :use softmax based network. : cls normalization modified with count of anchors by loss threthold : basenet - inceptionresnet : joint-training with different dataset was adaped but training was not finished until submission. (Currently, model performs better when trained jointly with imagenet detection dataset) * r-fcn with deformable conv : basenet - residual-net 101 ==> All meta framework was implemented by ourselfs with tensorflow. - resources : Training time:  9/18 ~ 9/30 : GPU Resoruce: Nvidia m40 x 60
We use a single model based on Faster RCNN and we don't use external dataset. we use skip connection for resnet152.

team.members: Zhenwen Zhu, Yayun Ji, Xiao Tian (PingAn AI Lab)
team.name: PingAn AI Lab

description: Our entry is based on Faster RCNN with end to end training. The model is fine-tuned with a ResNet-152 pre-trained model on ImageNet-1k. We perform multi-scale training using approximate FPN baseline setup and multi-scale testing. As post-processing, soft-NMS with box voting is applied to further improve average precision. Besides, ensemble of two faster RCNN based models which have different anchor settings do not contribute much to overall performance(1 model:40.9%, 2 models: 41.1%). We do not use any external data.

team.members: Shu Liu [a], Lu Qi [a], Haifang Qin [b], Jianping Shi [b], Jiaya Jia [a]; [a] The Chinese University of Hong Kong, [b] Sensetime
team.name: UCenter

description: We develop a novel region-based object detection and instance segmentation approach by boosting information flow from across layers, iterative pyramid and global context information. We use a feature pyramid Mask RCNN as our backbone [1, 2]. Our contributions are listed as follows. 1) Instead of assigning object proposals to different levels by a heuristic metric, we allow each proposal adaptively to pick useful information from all levels, leading to improved information flow from across layers. 2) We augment another path from lower layers to top layers based on the observation that larger objects could surprisingly benefit more from lower layer features, resulting in improved information flow from iterative pyramid. 3) We augment the FCN-like mask prediction branch with tiny fully-connected layers, improving information flow from global context information when predicting pixel-wise mask. As a result, masks with higher quality are produced. Our models are pre-trained on ImageNet and fine-tuned on COCO trainval subset with mask annotations. We directly take the tighten bounding boxes around each mask prediction as our object detection results. Our best single model performance is 44 in terms of instance segmentation and 47.8 in terms of object detection on test-dev subset. We find that the performances based on Resnext-101 (64*4d), SE-ResNext-101 (32*4d), Resnet-269 and SENet are just comparable. We hypothesis the reason is that the limited GPU memory makes the larger models can only be trained on smaller image input which limits their capability. For ensemble, we used 3 Resnext-101 (64*4d), 2 Se-ResNext-101 (32*4d), 1 Resnet-269 and 1 SENet. With network ensemble, we achieve 46.7 in terms of instance segmentation and 51 in terms of object detection on test-dev subset. [1] T. Lin, P. Dolla ́r, R. B. Girshick, K. He, B. Hariharan, and S. J. Belongie. Feature pyramid networks for object detection. CVPR 2017. [2] K. He, G. Gkioxari, P. Dolla ́r and R. B. Girshick. Mask R-CNN. ICCV 2017.

team.members: Lu Yang (BUPT Priv Lab); Qing Song (BUPT Priv Lab); Zuoxin Li (BUAA); Zhiwei Liu (CASIA)
team.name: BUPT-Priv

description: We propose a novel object detection network, named Context Pyramid Attention Network (CPANet). CPANet effectively integrates image context and spatial pyramid feature, and it is more accurate than the R-FCN baseline. In order to obtain higher accuracy, we train the Aligned Inception-ResNet101 on ImageNet-1k as our feature extractors, and then fine-tune it on the MSCOCO2017 trainval set.  This entry reports single model accuracy with multi-scale and horizontal flipping training. In test phase, we only adopt soft-nms without other bells and whistles (like multi-scale or multi-crop testing).
A PVANET trained on coco 2014 train/val and our own data.

We use 5x DeNet-101 models with the Joint Fitness NMS (unpublished) method. Models were trained at 512x512 and tested with 6x scales with the largest dimension resized to [384,512,768,1024,1280,1536]. A pretrained ImageNet ResNet-101 model is used as the base model. Method does not use RoI anchors / priors (reducing manual engineering), instead corner estimation and a Naive Bayes classifier is used for RoI estimation. RoI pooling is performed via Nearest Neighbour sampling on a spatially large top most feature map, providing improved evaluation rates. Multi scale, Single Model Performance: 42.3% MAP on test-challenge2017 Single Scale, Single Model Performance: 39.2% MAP @ 10 Hz on Titan X (Maxwell) on test-dev2017. ​Project URL: https://github.com/lachlants/denet Publication URL: https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.10295
